title: 104_s2038
content: The Act titled "Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System Act of 1996" is established for the purpose of providing findings and purposes. The Congress finds that there are insufficient water supplies of poor quality in the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System in Fall River County, South Dakota, posing a threat to public health and safety. Severe droughts have left residents without a satisfactory water supply, forcing them to haul water for their needs. Members of the district must either use bottled water or distillers due to the poor water quality available. The Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System in South Dakota faces poor water quality, leading residents to rely on distillers or bottled water. The system includes a Madison Aquifer well, water storage reservoirs, pumping stations, and pipelines to provide a safe and reliable water supply. The purpose of the system is to ensure a sufficient water supply for municipal, rural, and industrial needs in Fall River County. The Fall River Water Users District in South Dakota aims to develop safe water supplies for municipal, rural, and industrial needs. They also promote water conservation programs within the district. The Fall River Water Users District in South Dakota focuses on providing safe water supplies for various needs and promoting water conservation programs within the district. The Act defines key terms related to the Fall River Water Users District, including the engineering report, project construction budget, and pumping and operational requirements for water supply systems. The Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System delivers water to retail entities for individual users. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The "water supply system" is established and operated in accordance with a feasibility study. Federal assistance is provided for the water supply system. The Secretary can grant funds to the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System for planning and constructing a water supply system. The system will serve municipal, rural, and industrial water needs within specific boundaries. Grants will not exceed the authorized amount under section 10. The Secretary must not exceed the authorized amount for construction funds and must meet certain requirements before obligating funds for the water supply system, including compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act, submission of a final engineering report to Congress, and implementation of a water conservation program. SEC. 5. WATER CONSERVATION. The water conservation program aims to promote water conservation through technology and management techniques. It includes standards for plumbing fixtures, leak detection, rate structures, public education, and coordination between water systems. The programs will be reviewed and revised periodically. The water conservation program includes standards for plumbing fixtures, leak detection, rate structures, public education, and coordination between water systems. Provisions for periodic review and revision in cooperation with the Secretary are also included. Mitigation of fish and wildlife losses for the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System will be based on ecological equivalency, on an acre-for-acre basis during project construction. The use of Pick-Sloan Power is also authorized. The Western Area Power Administration will provide capacity and energy for irrigation and drainage pumping for the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program from May 1 to October 31 each year. The water supply system must operate on a not-for-profit basis and purchase all electric service requirements from a qualified preference power supplier. The Western Area Power Administration will provide capacity and energy for irrigation and drainage pumping for the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program. The rate schedule for the power delivery will be based on the firm power rate schedule of the Pick-Sloan Eastern Division. A contract will be agreed upon by the Western Area Power Administration, the power supplier, the entity receiving the power, and the Fall River Water Users District to pass through the benefit of the rate schedule to the water system. The power supplier will pass through charges to the water supply system, but can include other customary charges in the electric service fees. SEC. 8. NO LIMITATION ON WATER PROJECTS IN STATE. This Act does not limit authorization for water projects in South Dakota. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS. This Act does not affect State water law, interstate compacts, or water rights. SEC. 10. FEDERAL COST SHARE. SEC. 10. FEDERAL COST SHARE. The Secretary can provide funds equal to 80% of the project construction budget for the water supply system under section 4, and cover increases in development costs. SEC. 11. NON-FEDERAL COST SHARE. The non-Federal share of costs for the water supply system is 20% of the project construction budget and covers increases in development costs. SEC. 12. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AUTHORIZATION. SEC. 12. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AUTHORIZATION. The Secretary authorizes the Bureau of Reclamation to oversee construction of the water supply system in specified areas. The Bureau's funds for planning and construction cannot exceed 3% of the total project budget for the portion in Fall River County, South Dakota. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,600,000 is authorized for planning and construction of the water system under section 4, with additional funds for cost increases after August 1, 1995.
